Mail SMTP by WPForms";s:4:"slug";s:12:"wp-mail-smtp";s:7:"version";s:5:"1.9.0";s:6:"author";s:42:"<a href="https://wpforms.com/">WPForms</a>";s:14:"author_profile";s:35:"https://profiles.wordpress.org/smub";s:8:"requires";s:3:"4.9";s:6:"tested";s:5:"5.3.2";s:12:"requires_php";s:3:"5.3";s:13:"compatibility";a:0:{}s:6:"rating";d:86;s:7:"ratings";a:5:{i:5;i:325;i:4;i:19;i:3;i:14;i:2;i:13;i:1;i:56;}s:11:"num_ratings";i:427;s:15:"support_threads";i:76;s:24:"support_threads_resolved";i:66;s:10:"downloaded";i:11683486;s:12:"last_updated";s:21:"2020-03-23 4:45pm GMT";s:5:"added";s:10:"2007-09-12";s:8:"homepage";s:23:"https://wpmailsmtp.com/";s:8:"sections";a:5:{s:11:"description";s:11631:"<h3>WordPress Mail SMTP Plugin</h3>
<p>Having problems with your WordPress site not sending emails? You&#8217;re not alone. Over 1 million websites use WP Mail SMTP to send their emails reliably.</p>
<p>Our goal is to make email deliverability easy and reliable. We want to ensure your emails reach the inbox.</p>
<p>WP Mail SMTP fixes your email deliverability by reconfiguring WordPress to use a proper SMTP provider when sending emails.</p>
<h4>What is SMTP?</h4>
<p>SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an industry standard for sending emails. Proper SMTP configuration helps increase email deliverability by using authentication.</p>
<p>Popular email clients like Gmail, Yahoo, and Office 365 are in a constant battle with email spammers. One of the things they look at is if an email is originating from the location it claims to be originating from.</p>
<p>If the proper authentication isn&#8217;t there, then emails either go in the SPAM folder or worst, don&#8217;t get delivered at all.</p>
<p>This is a problem for a lot of WordPress sites because by default, WordPress uses the PHP mail function to send emails generated by WordPress or any contact form plugin like <a href="https://wpforms.com/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">WPForms</a>.</p>
<p>The issue is that most <a  rel="friend nofollow ugc">WordPress hosting companies</a> don&#8217;t have their servers properly configured for sending PHP emails.</p>
<p>The combination of two causes your WordPress emails to not get delivered.</p>
<h4>How does WP Mail SMTP work?</h4>
<p>WP Mail SMTP plugin easily resolves email delivery problems by improving and changing how your WordPress site sends email. We reconfigure the <code>wp_mail()</code> function to either use proper SMTP host credentials or leverage a built-in SMTP mail provider.</p>
<p>When using one of our built-in SMTP mail provider integrations (recommended), emails are sent using the provider&#8217;s direct API. This means even if your web host is blocking SMTP ports, your emails still send successfully.</p>
<p>This helps you fix all WordPress not sending email issues.</p>
<p>WP Mail SMTP plugin includes many different SMTP setup options:</p>
<ol>
<li>Pepipost SMTP <strong>(Recommended)</strong></li>
<li>Sendinblue SMTP <strong>(Recommended)</strong></li>
<li>Mailgun SMTP</li>
<li>SendGrid SMTP</li>
<li>Gmail SMTP</li>
<li>Microsoft SMTP (Outlook.com and Office 365) <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/?utm_source=wprepo&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_campaign=liteversion&amp;utm_content=readme" rel="friend nofollow ugc">[Pro]</a></li>
<li>Amazon SES SMTP <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/?utm_source=wprepo&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_campaign=liteversion&amp;utm_content=readme" rel="friend nofollow ugc">[Pro]</a></li>
<li>All Other SMTP</li>
</ol>
<p>For all options, you can specify the &#8220;from name&#8221; and &#8220;email address&#8221; for outgoing emails.</p>
<p>Instead of having users use different SMTP plugins and workflows for different SMTP providers, we decided to bring it all in one. This is what makes WP Mail SMTP, the best SMTP solution for WordPress.</p>
<h4>Pepipost SMTP</h4>
<p>Pepipost is a recommended transactional email service.</p>
<p>Every month they delivers over 8 billion emails from 20,000+ customers.</p>
<p>Their mission is to reliably send emails in the most efficient way and at the most disruptive pricing ever.<br />
Pepipost provides users 30,000 emails the first 30 days.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-pepipost-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Pepipost documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Sendinblue SMTP</h4>
<p>Sendinblue is a recommended transactional email service.</p>
<p>They serve 80,000+ growing companies around the world and send over 30 million emails each day.</p>
<p>Their email deliverability experts are constantly at work optimizing the reliability and speed of their SMTP infrastructure. Sendinblue provides users 300 free emails per day.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-sendinblue-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Sendinblue documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Mailgun SMTP</h4>
<p>Mailgun SMTP is a popular SMTP service provider that allows you to send large quantities of emails. They provide 5,000 free emails per month for 3 months.</p>
<p>WP Mail SMTP plugin offers a native integration with MailGun. All you have to do is connect your Mailgun account, and you will improve your email deliverability.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-mailgun-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Mailgun documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>SendGrid SMTP</h4>
<p>SendGrid has a free SMTP plan that you can use to send up to 100 emails per day. With our native SendGrid SMTP integration, you can easily and securely set up SendGrid SMTP on your WordPress site.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-sendgrid-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">SendGrid documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Gmail SMTP</h4>
<p>Often bloggers and small business owners don&#8217;t want to use third-party SMTP services. Well you can use your Gmail or G Suite account for SMTP emails.</p>
<p>This allows you to use your <a href="http://www.wpbeginner.com/beginners-guide/how-to-setup-a-professional-email-address-with-gmail-and-google-apps/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">professional email address</a> and improve email deliverability.</p>
<p>Unlike other Gmail SMTP plugins, our Gmail SMTP option uses OAuth to authenticate your Google account, keeping your login information 100% secure.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-gmail-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Gmail documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Microsoft SMTP (Outlook.com and Office 365)</h4>
<p>Many business use Outlook.com or Office 365 to their to power their email. For those users, the Microsoft mailer can be a great option. This integration allows you to use your existing Outlook.com or Office 365 account to send your emails reliably.</p>
<h4>Amazon SES SMTP</h4>
<p>Advanced or technical users can harness the power of Amazon AWS (Amazon Web Services) with the Amazon SES mailer. With this integration, you can send a high volume of emails at a very reasonable rate.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-amazon-ses-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Amazon SES documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Other SMTP</h4>
<p>WP Mail SMTP plugin also works with all major email services such as Gmail, Yahoo, Outlook, Microsoft Live, and any other email sending service that offers SMTP.</p>
<p>You can set the following options:</p>
<ul>
<li>Specify an SMTP host.</li>
<li>Specify an SMTP port.</li>
<li>Choose SSL / TLS encryption.</li>
<li>Choose to use SMTP authentication or not.</li>
<li>Specify an SMTP username and password.</li>
</ul>
<p>To see recommended settings for the popular services as well as troubleshooting tips, check out our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-other-smtp-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">SMTP documentation</a>.</p>
<p>We hope that you find WP Mail SMTP plugin helpful!</p>
<h3>WP Mail SMTP PRO</h3>
<p>In addition to native Microsoft and Amazon SES integrations, WP Mail SMTP Pro provides access to many other powerful features and services.</p>
<p><a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/?utm_source=wprepo&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_campaign=liteversion&amp;utm_content=readme" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Click here to purchase WP Mail SMTP Pro now!</a></p>
<h4>Email Log</h4>
<p>Email Logging lets you log and view all emails sent from your site. Email logs are helpful for storing emails for your records, auditing outgoing emails, and debugging during site development.</p>
<h4>Manage WordPress Emails and Notifications</h4>
<p>The Manage Notification feature gives you full control over which email notifications WordPress sends. This means you can disable different WordPress notification emails. Don&#8217;t want to receive emails when new users are created? No problem, turn it off.</p>
<h4>Expert Support</h4>
<p>We provide <a href="https://wordpress.org/support/topic/wp-mail-smtp-support-policy/">limited support</a> for the WP Mail SMTP plugin on the WordPress.org forums. Access to our world class one-on-one email support is available to <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/?utm_source=wprepo&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_campaign=liteversion&amp;utm_content=readme" rel="friend nofollow ugc">WP Mail SMTP Pro</a> users.</p>
<h4>White Glove Setup</h4>
<p>Our White Glove Setup service is a great option that anyone can benefit from. Whether you don&#8217;t have the time or maybe you feel a bit in over your head &#8211; we&#8217;ve got you covered.</p>
<p>You can sit back and relax while we set up everything for you. White glove setup includes WP Mail SMTP plugin installation and setup, configuration adjustments to your DNS for proper email domain name verification, Mailgun setup, and final testing to confirm everything is passing with flying colors.</p>
<h3>Security</h3>
<p>The WP Mail SMTP team takes security very seriously. Not only does the plugin follow all security best practices, but we have several options available to ensure your site is safe and secure.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Direct SMTP mailer integrations (recommended), such as Google and Mailgun, use the official provider APIs. This means you never enter your username or password in the plugin settings and these credentials are not stored in the database. Instead, we use tokens or API keys which are much more secure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When using Other SMTP mailer, we provide the option to insert your password in your <code>wp-config.php</code> file, so it&#8217;s not visible in your WordPress settings or saved in the database.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<h4>Can I use this plugin to send email via Gmail, G Suite, Outlook.com, Office 365, Hotmail, Yahoo, or AOL SMTP?</h4>
<p>
<p>Yes! We have extensive documentation that covers setting up SMTP most popular email services.</p>
<p><a href="https://wpforms.com/docs/how-to-set-up-smtp-using-the-wp-mail-smtp-plugin/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Read our docs</a> to see the correct SMTP settings for each service.</p>
</p>
<h4>Help! I need support or have an issue.</h4>
<p>
<p>Please read <a href="https://wordpress.org/support/topic/wp-mail-smtp-support-policy/">our support policy</a> for more information.</p>
<p>Limited support is available for WP Mail SMTP users via WordPress.org support forums.</p>
<p>Email support and set up assistance is available to WP Mail SMTP Pro users.</p>
</p>
<h4>I found a bug, now what?</h4>
<p>
<p>If you&#8217;ve stumbled upon a bug, the best place to report it is in the <a href="https://github.com/awesomemotive/wp-mail-smtp" rel="nofollow ugc">WP Mail SMTP GitHub repository</a>. GitHub is where the plugin is actively developed, and posting there will get your issue quickly seen by our developers (myself and Slava). Once posted, we&#8217;ll review your bug report and triage the bug. When creating an issue, the more details you can add to your report, the faster the bug can be solved.</p>
</p>
<h4>Can you add feature x, y or z to the plugin?</h4>
<p>
<p>Short answer: maybe.</p>
<p>By all means please contact us to discuss features or options you&#8217;d like to see added to the plugin. We can&#8217;t guarantee to add all of them, but we will consider all sensible requests. We can be contacted here:<br />
<a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/contact/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">https://wpmailsmtp.com/contact/</a></p>
</p>

";s:11:"screenshots";s:1315:"<ol><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-1.png?rev=1785565"><img src="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-1.png?rev=1785565" alt="WP Mail SMTP Settings page"></a><p>WP Mail SMTP Settings page</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-2.png?rev=1785565"><img src="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-2.png?rev=1785565" alt="Gmail / G Suite settings"></a><p>Gmail / G Suite settings</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-3.png?rev=1785565"><img src="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-3.png?rev=1785565" alt="Mailgun settings"></a><p>Mailgun settings</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-4.png?rev=1785565"><img src="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-4.png?rev=1785565" alt="SendGrid settings"></a><p>SendGrid settings</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-5.png?rev=1785565"><img src="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-5.png?rev=1785565" alt="SMTP settings"></a><p>SMTP settings</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-6.png?rev=1785565"><img src="https://ps.w.org/wp-mail-smtp/assets/screenshot-6.png?rev=1785565" alt="Send a Test Email"></a><p>Send a Test Email</p></li></ol>";}s:11:"description";s:11631:"<h3>WordPress Mail SMTP Plugin</h3>
<p>Having problems with your WordPress site not sending emails? You&#8217;re not alone. Over 1 million websites use WP Mail SMTP to send their emails reliably.</p>
<p>Our goal is to make email deliverability easy and reliable. We want to ensure your emails reach the inbox.</p>
<p>WP Mail SMTP fixes your email deliverability by reconfiguring WordPress to use a proper SMTP provider when sending emails.</p>
<h4>What is SMTP?</h4>
<p>SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an industry standard for sending emails. Proper SMTP configuration helps increase email deliverability by using authentication.</p>
<p>Popular email clients like Gmail, Yahoo, and Office 365 are in a constant battle with email spammers. One of the things they look at is if an email is originating from the location it claims to be originating from.</p>
<p>If the proper authentication isn&#8217;t there, then emails either go in the SPAM folder or worst, don&#8217;t get delivered at all.</p>
<p>This is a problem for a lot of WordPress sites because by default, WordPress uses the PHP mail function to send emails generated by WordPress or any contact form plugin like <a href="https://wpforms.com/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">WPForms</a>.</p>
<p>The issue is that most <a  rel="friend nofollow ugc">WordPress hosting companies</a> don&#8217;t have their servers properly configured for sending PHP emails.</p>
<p>The combination of two causes your WordPress emails to not get delivered.</p>
<h4>How does WP Mail SMTP work?</h4>
<p>WP Mail SMTP plugin easily resolves email delivery problems by improving and changing how your WordPress site sends email. We reconfigure the <code>wp_mail()</code> function to either use proper SMTP host credentials or leverage a built-in SMTP mail provider.</p>
<p>When using one of our built-in SMTP mail provider integrations (recommended), emails are sent using the provider&#8217;s direct API. This means even if your web host is blocking SMTP ports, your emails still send successfully.</p>
<p>This helps you fix all WordPress not sending email issues.</p>
<p>WP Mail SMTP plugin includes many different SMTP setup options:</p>
<ol>
<li>Pepipost SMTP <strong>(Recommended)</strong></li>
<li>Sendinblue SMTP <strong>(Recommended)</strong></li>
<li>Mailgun SMTP</li>
<li>SendGrid SMTP</li>
<li>Gmail SMTP</li>
<li>Microsoft SMTP (Outlook.com and Office 365) <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/?utm_source=wprepo&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_campaign=liteversion&amp;utm_content=readme" rel="friend nofollow ugc">[Pro]</a></li>
<li>Amazon SES SMTP <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/?utm_source=wprepo&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_campaign=liteversion&amp;utm_content=readme" rel="friend nofollow ugc">[Pro]</a></li>
<li>All Other SMTP</li>
</ol>
<p>For all options, you can specify the &#8220;from name&#8221; and &#8220;email address&#8221; for outgoing emails.</p>
<p>Instead of having users use different SMTP plugins and workflows for different SMTP providers, we decided to bring it all in one. This is what makes WP Mail SMTP, the best SMTP solution for WordPress.</p>
<h4>Pepipost SMTP</h4>
<p>Pepipost is a recommended transactional email service.</p>
<p>Every month they delivers over 8 billion emails from 20,000+ customers.</p>
<p>Their mission is to reliably send emails in the most efficient way and at the most disruptive pricing ever.<br />
Pepipost provides users 30,000 emails the first 30 days.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-pepipost-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Pepipost documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Sendinblue SMTP</h4>
<p>Sendinblue is a recommended transactional email service.</p>
<p>They serve 80,000+ growing companies around the world and send over 30 million emails each day.</p>
<p>Their email deliverability experts are constantly at work optimizing the reliability and speed of their SMTP infrastructure. Sendinblue provides users 300 free emails per day.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-sendinblue-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Sendinblue documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Mailgun SMTP</h4>
<p>Mailgun SMTP is a popular SMTP service provider that allows you to send large quantities of emails. They provide 5,000 free emails per month for 3 months.</p>
<p>WP Mail SMTP plugin offers a native integration with MailGun. All you have to do is connect your Mailgun account, and you will improve your email deliverability.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-mailgun-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Mailgun documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>SendGrid SMTP</h4>
<p>SendGrid has a free SMTP plan that you can use to send up to 100 emails per day. With our native SendGrid SMTP integration, you can easily and securely set up SendGrid SMTP on your WordPress site.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-sendgrid-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">SendGrid documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Gmail SMTP</h4>
<p>Often bloggers and small business owners don&#8217;t want to use third-party SMTP services. Well you can use your Gmail or G Suite account for SMTP emails.</p>
<p>This allows you to use your <a href="http://www.wpbeginner.com/beginners-guide/how-to-setup-a-professional-email-address-with-gmail-and-google-apps/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">professional email address</a> and improve email deliverability.</p>
<p>Unlike other Gmail SMTP plugins, our Gmail SMTP option uses OAuth to authenticate your Google account, keeping your login information 100% secure.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-gmail-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Gmail documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Microsoft SMTP (Outlook.com and Office 365)</h4>
<p>Many business use Outlook.com or Office 365 to their to power their email. For those users, the Microsoft mailer can be a great option. This integration allows you to use your existing Outlook.com or Office 365 account to send your emails reliably.</p>
<h4>Amazon SES SMTP</h4>
<p>Advanced or technical users can harness the power of Amazon AWS (Amazon Web Services) with the Amazon SES mailer. With this integration, you can send a high volume of emails at a very reasonable rate.</p>
<p>Read our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-amazon-ses-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Amazon SES documentation</a> for more details.</p>
<h4>Other SMTP</h4>
<p>WP Mail SMTP plugin also works with all major email services such as Gmail, Yahoo, Outlook, Microsoft Live, and any other email sending service that offers SMTP.</p>
<p>You can set the following options:</p>
<ul>
<li>Specify an SMTP host.</li>
<li>Specify an SMTP port.</li>
<li>Choose SSL / TLS encryption.</li>
<li>Choose to use SMTP authentication or not.</li>
<li>Specify an SMTP username and password.</li>
</ul>
<p>To see recommended settings for the popular services as well as troubleshooting tips, check out our <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/docs/how-to-set-up-the-other-smtp-mailer-in-wp-mail-smtp/" rel="friend nofollow ugc">SMTP documentation</a>.</p>
<p>We hope that you find WP Mail SMTP plugin helpful!</p>
<h3>WP Mail SMTP PRO</h3>
<p>In addition to native Microsoft and Amazon SES integrations, WP Mail SMTP Pro provides access to many other powerful features and services.</p>
<p><a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/?utm_source=wprepo&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_campaign=liteversion&amp;utm_content=readme" rel="friend nofollow ugc">Click here to purchase WP Mail SMTP Pro now!</a></p>
<h4>Email Log</h4>
<p>Email Logging lets you log and view all emails sent from your site. Email logs are helpful for storing emails for your records, auditing outgoing emails, and debugging during site development.</p>
<h4>Manage WordPress Emails and Notifications</h4>
<p>The Manage Notification feature gives you full control over which email notifications WordPress sends. This means you can disable different WordPress notification emails. Don&#8217;t want to receive emails when new users are created? No problem, turn it off.</p>
<h4>Expert Support</h4>
<p>We provide <a href="https://wordpress.org/support/topic/wp-mail-smtp-support-policy/">limited support</a> for the WP Mail SMTP plugin on the WordPress.org forums. Access to our world class one-on-one email support is available to <a href="https://wpmailsmtp.com/?utm_source=wprepo&amp;utm_medium=link&amp;utm_campaign=liteversion&amp;utm_content=readme" rel="friend nofollow ugc">WP Mail SMTP Pro</a> users.</p>
<h4>White Glove Setup</h4>
<p>Our White Glove Setup service is a great option that anyone can benefit from. Whether you don&#8217;t have the time or maybe you feel a bit in over your head &#8211; we&#8217;ve got you covered.</p>
<p>You can sit back and relax while we set up everything for you. White glove setup includes WP Mail SMTP plugin installation and setup, configuration adjustments to your DNS for proper email domain name verification, Mailgun setup, and final testing to confirm everything is passing with flying colors.</p>
<h3>Security</h3>
<p>The WP Mail SMTP team takes security very seriously. Not only does the plugin follow all security best practices, but we have several options available to ensure your site is safe and secure.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Direct SMTP mailer integrations (recommended), such as Google and Mailgun, use the official provider APIs. This means you never enter your username or password in the plugin settings and these credentials are not stored in the database. Instead, we use tokens or API keys which are much more secure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When using Other SMTP mailer, we provide the option to insert your password in your <code>wp-config.php</code> file, so it&#8217;s not visible in your WordPress settings or saved in the database.</p>
</li>
</ul>

Godley";s:14:"author_profile";s:38:"https://profiles.wordpress.org/johnny5";s:8:"requires";s:3:"4.9";s:6:"tested";s:3:"5.4";s:12:"requires_php";s:3:"5.6";s:13:"compatibility";a:0:{}s:6:"rating";d:86;s:7:"ratings";a:5:{i:5;i:378;i:4;i:30;i:3;i:11;i:2;i:20;i:1;i:60;}s:11:"num_ratings";i:499;s:15:"support_threads";i:107;s:24:"support_threads_resolved";i:101;s:10:"downloaded";i:23378571;s:12:"last_updated";s:21:"2020-04-01 5:37am GMT";s:5:"added";s:10:"2007-09-10";s:8:"homepage";s:23:"https://redirection.me/";s:8:"sections";a:5:{s:11:"description";s:5136:"<p>Redirection is the most popular redirect manager for WordPress. With it you can easily manage 301 redirections, keep track of 404 errors, and generally tidy up any loose ends your site may have. This can help reduce errors and improve your site ranking.</p>
<p>Redirection is designed to be used on sites with a few redirects to sites with thousands of redirects.</p>
<p>It has been a WordPress plugin for over 10 years and has been recommended countless times. And it&#8217;s free!</p>
<p>Full documentation can be found at <a href="https://redirection.me" rel="nofollow ugc">https://redirection.me</a></p>
<p>Redirection is compatible with PHP from 5.6 and upwards (including 7.4).</p>
<h4>Redirect manager</h4>
<p>Create and manage redirects quickly and easily without needing Apache or Nginx knowledge. If your WordPress supports permalinks then you can use Redirection to redirect any URL.</p>
<p>There is full support for regular expressions so you can create redirect patterns to match any number of URLs. You can match query parameters and even pass them through to the target URL.</p>
<p>The plugin can also be configured to monitor when post or page permalinks are changed and automatically create a redirect to the new URL.</p>
<h4>Conditional redirects</h4>
<p>In addition to straightforward URL matching you can redirect based on other conditions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Login status &#8211; redirect only if the user is logged in or logged out</li>
<li>WordPress capability &#8211; redirect if the user is able to perform a certain capability</li>
<li>Browser &#8211; redirect if the user is using a certain browser</li>
<li>Referrer &#8211; redirect if the user visited the link from another page</li>
<li>Cookies &#8211; redirect if a particular cookie is set</li>
<li>HTTP headers &#8211; redirect based on a HTTP header</li>
<li>Custom filter &#8211; redirect based on your own WordPress filter</li>
<li>IP address &#8211; redirect if the client IP address matches</li>
<li>Server &#8211; redirect another domain if also hosted on this server</li>
<li>Page type &#8211; redirect if the current page is a 404</li>
</ul>
<h4>Full logging</h4>
<p>A configurable logging option allows to view all redirects occurring on your site, including information about the visitor, the browser used, and the referrer. A &#8216;hit&#8217; count is maintained for each redirect so you can see if a URL is being used.</p>
<p>Logs can be exported for external viewing, and can be searched and filtered for more detailed investigation.</p>
<p>Display geographic information about an IP address, as well as a full user agent information, to try and understand who the visitor is.</p>
<p>You are able to disable or reduce IP collection to meet the legal requirements of your geographic region.</p>
<h4>Add HTTP headers</h4>
<p>HTTP headers can be adder to redirects or your entire site that help reduce the impact of redirects or help increase security. You can also add your own custom headers.</p>
<h4>Track 404 errors</h4>
<p>Redirection will keep track of all 404 errors that occur on your site, allowing you to track down and fix problems.</p>
<p>Errors can be grouped to show where you should focus your attention, and can be redirected in bulk.</p>
<h4>Query parameter handling</h4>
<p>You can match query parameters exactly, ignore them, and even pass them through to your target.</p>
<h4>Apache &amp; Nginx support</h4>
<p>By default Redirection will manage all redirects using WordPress. However you can configure it so redirects are automatically saved to a .htaccess file and handled by Apache itself.</p>
<p>If you use Nginx then you can export redirects to an Nginx rewrite rules file.</p>
<h4>Fine-grained permissions</h4>
<p>Fine-grained permissions are available so you can customise the plugin for different users. This makes it particularly suitable for client sites where you may want to prevent certain actions, and remove functionality.</p>
<h4>Import &amp; Export</h4>
<p>The plugin has a fully-featured import and export system and you can:</p>
<ul>
<li>Import and export to Apache .htaccess</li>
<li>Export to Nginx rewrite rules</li>
<li>Copy redirects between sites using JSON</li>
<li>Import and export to CSV for viewing in a spreadsheet</li>
<li>Use WP CLI to automate import and export</li>
</ul>
<p>You can also import from the following plugins:</p>
<ul>
<li>Simple 301 Redirects</li>
<li>SEO Redirection</li>
<li>Safe Redirect Manager</li>
<li>Rank Math</li>
<li>WordPress old slug redirects</li>
</ul>
<h4>Wait, it&#8217;s free?</h4>
<p>Yes, it&#8217;s really free. There&#8217;s no premium version and no need to pay money to get access to features. This is a dedicated redirect management plugin.</p>
<h3>Support</h3>
<p>Please submit bugs, patches, and feature requests to:</p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/johngodley/redirection" rel="nofollow ugc">https://github.com/johngodley/redirection</a></p>
<p>Please submit translations to:</p>
<p><a href="https://translate.wordpress.org/projects/wp-plugins/redirection" rel="nofollow ugc">https://translate.wordpress.org/projects/wp-plugins/redirection</a></p>
";s:12:"installation";s:652:"<p>The plugin is simple to install:</p>
<ol>
<li>Download <code>redirection.zip</code></li>
<li>Unzip</li>
<li>Upload <code>redirection</code> directory to your <code>/wp-content/plugins</code> directory</li>
<li>Go to the plugin management page and enable the plugin</li>
<li>Configure the options from the <code>Manage/Redirection</code> page</li>
</ol>
<p>You can find full details of installing a plugin on the <a href="https://redirection.me/support/installation/" rel="nofollow ugc">plugin installation page</a>.</p>
<p>Full documentation can be found on the <a href="https://redirection.me/support/" rel="nofollow ugc">Redirection</a> page.</p>
";s:3:"faq";s:517:"
<h4>Why would I want to use this instead of .htaccess?</h4>
<p>
<p>Ease of use.  Redirections are automatically created when a post URL changes, and it is a lot easier to manually add redirections than to hack around a .htaccess.  You also get the added benefit of being able to keep track of 404 errors.</p>
</p>
<h4>What is the performance of this plugin?</h4>
<p>
<p>The plugin works in a similar manner to how WordPress handles permalinks and should not result in any noticeable slowdown to your site.</p>
</p>

";s:9:"changelog";s:24746:"<p>An x.1 version increase introduces new or updated features and can be considered to contain &#8216;breaking&#8217; changes. A x.x.1 increase is<br />
purely a bug fix and introduces no new features, and can be considered as containing no breaking changes.</p>
<h4>4.7.1 &#8211; 14th March 2020</h4>
<ul>
<li>Fix HTTP header over-sanitizing the value</li>
<li>Fix inability to remove .htaccess location</li>
<li>Fix 404 group by &#8216;delete all&#8217;</li>
<li>Fix import of empty &#8216;old slugs&#8217;</li>
</ul>
<h4>4.7 &#8211; 15th February 2020</h4>
<ul>
<li>Relocate entire site to another domain, with exceptions</li>
<li>Site aliases to map another site to current site</li>
<li>Canonical settings for www/no-www</li>
<li>Change content-type for API requests to help with mod_security</li>
</ul>
<h4>4.6.2 &#8211; 6th January 2020</h4>
<ul>
<li>Fix 404 log export button</li>
<li>Fix HTTPS option not appearing enabled</li>
<li>Fix another PHP compat issue</li>
</ul>
<h4>4.6.1 &#8211; 30th December 2019</h4>
<ul>
<li>Back-compatibility fix for old PHP versions</li>
</ul>
<h4>4.6 &#8211; 27th December 2019</h4>
<ul>
<li>Add fine-grained permissions allowing greater customisation of the plugin, and removal of functionality</li>
<li>Add an import step to the install wizard</li>
<li>Remove overriding of default WordPress &#8216;old slugs&#8217;</li>
</ul>
<h4>4.5.1 &#8211; 23rd November 2019</h4>
<ul>
<li>Fix broken canonical redirects</li>
</ul>
<h4>4.5 &#8211; 23rd November 2019</h4>

";s:11:"screenshots";s:1261:"<ol><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-1.png?rev=1764489"><img src="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-1.png?rev=1764489" alt="Redirection management interface"></a><p>Redirection management interface</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-2.png?rev=1764495"><img src="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-2.png?rev=1764495" alt="Adding a redirection"></a><p>Adding a redirection</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-3.png?rev=1764491"><img src="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-3.png?rev=1764491" alt="Redirect logs"></a><p>Redirect logs</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-4.png?rev=1764495"><img src="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-4.png?rev=1764495" alt="Import/Export"></a><p>Import/Export</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-5.png?rev=1764493"><img src="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-5.png?rev=1764493" alt="Options"></a><p>Options</p></li><li><a href="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-6.png?rev=1764494"><img src="https://ps.w.org/redirection/assets/screenshot-6.png?rev=1764494" alt="Support"></a><p>Support</p></li></ol>";}s:11:"description";s:5136:"<p>Redirection is the most popular redirect manager for WordPress. With it you can easily manage 301 redirections, keep track of 404 errors, and generally tidy up any loose ends your site may have. This can help reduce errors and improve your site ranking.</p>
<p>Redirection is designed to be used on sites with a few redirects to sites with thousands of redirects.</p>
<p>It has been a WordPress plugin for over 10 years and has been recommended countless times. And it&#8217;s free!</p>
<p>Full documentation can be found at <a href="https://redirection.me" rel="nofollow ugc">https://redirection.me</a></p>
<p>Redirection is compatible with PHP from 5.6 and upwards (including 7.4).</p>
<h4>Redirect manager</h4>
<p>Create and manage redirects quickly and easily without needing Apache or Nginx knowledge. If your WordPress supports permalinks then you can use Redirection to redirect any URL.</p>
<p>There is full support for regular expressions so you can create redirect patterns to match any number of URLs. You can match query parameters and even pass them through to the target URL.</p>
<p>The plugin can also be configured to monitor when post or page permalinks are changed and automatically create a redirect to the new URL.</p>
<h4>Conditional redirects</h4>
<p>In addition to straightforward URL matching you can redirect based on other conditions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Login status &#8211; redirect only if the user is logged in or logged out</li>
<li>WordPress capability &#8211; redirect if the user is able to perform a certain capability</li>
<li>Browser &#8211; redirect if the user is using a certain browser</li>
<li>Referrer &#8211; redirect if the user visited the link from another page</li>
<li>Cookies &#8211; redirect if a particular cookie is set</li>
<li>HTTP headers &#8211; redirect based on a HTTP header</li>
<li>Custom filter &#8211; redirect based on your own WordPress filter</li>
<li>IP address &#8211; redirect if the client IP address matches</li>
<li>Server &#8211; redirect another domain if also hosted on this server</li>
<li>Page type &#8211; redirect if the current page is a 404</li>
</ul>
<h4>Full logging</h4>
<p>A configurable logging option allows to view all redirects occurring on your site, including information about the visitor, the browser used, and the referrer. A &#8216;hit&#8217; count is maintained for each redirect so you can see if a URL is being used.</p>
<p>Logs can be exported for external viewing, and can be searched and filtered for more detailed investigation.</p>
<p>Display geographic information about an IP address, as well as a full user agent information, to try and understand who the visitor is.</p>
<p>You are able to disable or reduce IP collection to meet the legal requirements of your geographic region.</p>
<h4>Add HTTP headers</h4>
<p>HTTP headers can be adder to redirects or your entire site that help reduce the impact of redirects or help increase security. You can also add your own custom headers.</p>
<h4>Track 404 errors</h4>
<p>Redirection will keep track of all 404 errors that occur on your site, allowing you to track down and fix problems.</p>
<p>Errors can be grouped to show where you should focus your attention, and can be redirected in bulk.</p>
<h4>Query parameter handling</h4>
<p>You can match query parameters exactly, ignore them, and even pass them through to your target.</p>
<h4>Apache &amp; Nginx support</h4>
<p>By default Redirection will manage all redirects using WordPress. However you can configure it so redirects are automatically saved to a .htaccess file and handled by Apache itself.</p>
<p>If you use Nginx then you can export redirects to an Nginx rewrite rules file.</p>
<h4>Fine-grained permissions</h4>
<p>Fine-grained permissions are available so you can customise the plugin for different users. This makes it particularly suitable for client sites where you may want to prevent certain actions, and remove functionality.</p>
<h4>Import &amp; Export</h4>
<p>The plugin has a fully-featured import and export system and you can:</p>
<ul>
<li>Import and export to Apache .htaccess</li>
<li>Export to Nginx rewrite rules</li>
<li>Copy redirects between sites using JSON</li>
<li>Import and export to CSV for viewing in a spreadsheet</li>
<li>Use WP CLI to automate import and export</li>
</ul>
<p>You can also import from the following plugins:</p>
<ul>
<li>Simple 301 Redirects</li>
<li>SEO Redirection</li>
<li>Safe Redirect Manager</li>
<li>Rank Math</li>
<li>WordPress old slug redirects</li>
</ul>
<h4>Wait, it&#8217;s free?</h4>
<p>Yes, it&#8217;s really free. There&#8217;s no premium version and no need to pay money to get access to features. This is a dedicated redirect management plugin.</p>
<h3>Support</h3>
<p>Please submit bugs, patches, and feature requests to:</p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/johngodley/redirection" rel="nofollow ugc">https://github.com/johngodley/redirection</a></p>
<p>Please submit translations to:</p>
<p><a href="https://translate.wordpress.org/projects/wp-plugins/redirection" rel="nofollow ugc">https://translate.wordpress.org/projects/wp-plugins/redirection</a></p>

1.zip";s:5:"4.1.1";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.1.1.zip";s:3:"4.2";s:58:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.2.zip";s:5:"4.2.1";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.2.1.zip";s:5:"4.2.2";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.2.2.zip";s:5:"4.2.3";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.2.3.zip";s:3:"4.3";s:58:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.3.zip";s:5:"4.3.1";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.3.1.zip";s:5:"4.3.2";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.3.2.zip";s:5:"4.3.3";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.3.3.zip";s:3:"4.4";s:58:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.4.zip";s:5:"4.4.1";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.4.1.zip";s:5:"4.4.2";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.4.2.zip";s:3:"4.5";s:58:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.5.zip";s:5:"4.5.1";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.5.1.zip";s:5:"4.6.2";s:60:"https://downloads.wordpress.org/plugin/redirection.4.6.2.zip";}s:11:"donate_link";s:32:"https://redirection.me/donation/";s:18:"author_block_count";i:0;s:19:"author_block_rating";d:86;}i:23;O:8:"stdClass":28:{s:4:"name";s:21:"Regenerate Thumbnails";s:4:"slug";s:21:"regenerate-thumbnails";s:7:"version";s:5:"3.1.3";s:6:"author";s:58:"<a href="https://alex.blog/">Alex Mills (Viper007Bond)</a>";s:14:"author_profile";s:41:"https://profiles.wordpress.org/automattic";s:8:"requires";s:3:"4.7";s:6:"tested";s:5:"5.3.2";s:12:"requires_php";s:5:"5.2.4";s:13:"compatibility";a:0:{}s:6:"rating";d:92;s:7:"ratings";a:5:{i:5;i:301;i:4;i:17;i:3;i:3;i:2;i:6;i:1;i:21;}s:11:"num_ratings";i:348;s:15:"support_threads";i:13;s:24:"support_threads_resolved";i:7;s:10:"downloaded";i:13860953;s:12:"last_updated";s:21:"2020-03-09 6:08pm GMT";s:5:"added";s:10:"2008-08-28";s:8:"homepage";s:58:"https://alex.blog/wordpress-plugins/regenerate-thumbnails/";s:8:"sections";a:5:{s:11:"description";s:2840:"<p>Regenerate Thumbnails allows you to regenerate all thumbnail sizes for one or more images that have been uploaded to your Media Library.</p>
<p>This is useful for situations such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>A new thumbnail size has been added and you want past uploads to have a thumbnail in that size.</li>
<li>You&#8217;ve changed the dimensions of an existing thumbnail size, for example via Settings → Media.</li>
<li>You&#8217;ve switched to a new WordPress theme that uses featured images of a different size.</li>
</ul>
<p>It also offers the ability to delete old, unused thumbnails in order to free up server space.</p>
<h4>In Memory of Alex Mills</h4>
<p>In February 2019 Alex Mills, the author of this plugin, <a href="https://alex.blog/2019/02/27/from-alexs-family/" rel="nofollow ugc">passed away</a>. He leaves behind a number of plugins which will be maintained by Automattic and members of the WordPress community. If this plugin is useful to you please consider donating to the Oregon Health and Science University. You can find more information <a href="https://alex.blog/2019/03/13/in-memory-of-alex-donation-link-update/" rel="nofollow ugc">here</a>.</p>
<h4>Alternatives</h4>
<p><strong>WP-CLI</strong></p>
<p>If you have command line access to your server, I highly recommend using <a href="https://wp-cli.org/" rel="nofollow ugc">WP-CLI</a> instead of this plugin as it&#8217;s faster (no HTTP requests overhead) and can be run inside of a <code>screen</code> for those with many thumbnails. For details, see the documentation of its <a href="https://developer.wordpress.org/cli/commands/media/regenerate/" rel="nofollow ugc"><code>media regenerate</code> command</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Jetpack&#8217;s Photon Module</strong></p>
<p><a href="https://jetpack.com/" rel="nofollow ugc">Jetpack</a> is a plugin by Automattic, makers of WordPress.com. It gives your self-hosted WordPress site some of the functionality that is available to WordPress.com-hosted sites.</p>
<p><a href="https://jetpack.com/support/photon/" rel="nofollow ugc">The Photon module</a> makes the images on your site be served from WordPress.com&#8217;s global content delivery network (CDN) which should speed up the loading of images. Importantly though it can create thumbnails on the fly which means you&#8217;ll never need to use this plugin.</p>
<p>I personally use Photon on my own website.</p>
<p><em>Disclaimer: I work for Automattic but I would recommend Photon even if I didn&#8217;t.</em></p>
<h4>Need Help? Found A Bug? Want To Contribute Code?</h4>
<p>Support for this plugin is provided via the <a href="https://wordpress.org/support/plugin/regenerate-thumbnails">WordPress.org forums</a>.</p>
<p>The source code for this plugin is available on <a href="https://github.com/automattic/regenerate-thumbnails" rel="nofollow ugc">GitHub</a>.</p>
";s:12:"installation";s:248:"<ol>
<li>Go to your admin area and select Plugins → Add New from the menu.</li>
<li>Search for &#8220;Regenerate Thumbnails&#8221;.</li>
<li>Click install.</li>
<li>Click activate.</li>
<li>Navigate to Tools → Regenerate Thumbnails.</li>
</ol>
";s:3:"faq";s:347:"
<h4>Is this plugin [GDPR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Data_Protection_Regulation) compliant?</h4>
<p>
<p>This plugin does not log nor transmit any user data. Infact it doesn&#8217;t even do anything on the user-facing part of your website, only in the admin area. This means it should be compliant but I&#8217;m not a lawyer.</p>
</p>

";s:9:"changelog";s:6263:"<h4>Version 3.1.3</h4>
<ul>
<li>Update plugin dependencies to the latest version.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 3.1.2</h4>
<ul>
<li>Use wp_get_original_image_path() in WordPress 5.3</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 3.1.1</h4>
<ul>
<li>Minor fix to avoid a divide by zero error when displaying thumbnail filenames.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 3.1.0</h4>
<ul>
<li>Bring back the ability to delete old, unregistered thumbnail sizes. Support for updating post contents is still disabled (too buggy).</li>
<li>Various code improvements including string localization disambiguation.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 3.0.2</h4>
<ul>
<li>Fix slowdown in certain cases in the media library.</li>
<li>Fix not being able to regenerate existing thumbnails for single images. Props @idofri.</li>
<li>Fix JavaScript error that could occur if the REST API response was unexpected (empty or PHP error).</li>
<li>Fix bug related to multibyte filenames.</li>
<li>If an image is used as the featured image on multiple posts, only regenerate it once instead of once per post.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 3.0.1</h4>
<ul>
<li>Temporarily disable the update post functionality. I tested it a lot but it seems there&#8217;s still some bugs.</li>
<li>Temporarily disable the delete old thumbnails functionality. It seems to work fine but without the update post functionality, it&#8217;s not as useful.</li>
<li>Try to more gracefully handle cases where there&#8217;s missing metadata for attachments.</li>
<li>Wait until <code>init</code> to initialize the plugin so themes can filter the plugin&#8217;s capability. <code>plugins_loaded</code> is too early.</li>
<li>Fix a JavaScript error that would cause the whole regeneration process to stop if an individual image returned non-JSON, such as a 500 error code.</li>
<li>Accept GET requests for the regenerate REST API endpoint instead of just POSTs. For some reasons some people&#8217;s sites are using GET despite the code saying use POST.</li>
<li>Make the attachment ID clickable in error messages.</li>
<li>Fetch 25 attachments at a time instead of 5. I was using 5 for testing.</li>
<li>PHP notice fixes.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 3.0.0</h4>
<ul>
<li>Complete rewrite from scratch using Vue.js and the WordPress REST API.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.2.4</h4>
<ul>
<li>Better AJAX response error handling in the JavaScript. This should fix a long-standing bug in this plugin. Props Hew Sutton.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.2.3</h4>
<ul>
<li>Make the capability required to use this plugin filterable so themes and other plugins can change it. Props <a href="http://jacksonwhelan.com/" rel="nofollow ugc">Jackson Whelan</a>.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.2.2</h4>
<ul>
<li>Don&#8217;t check the nonce until we&#8217;re sure that the action called was for this plugin. Fixes lots of &#8220;Are you sure you want to do this?&#8221; error messages.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.2.1</h4>
<ul>
<li>Fix the bottom bulk action dropdown. Thanks Stefan for pointing out the issue!</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.2.0</h4>
<ul>
<li>Changes to the Bulk Action functionality were made shortly before the release of WordPress 3.1 which broke the way I implemented the specific multiple image regeneration feature. This version adds to the Bulk Action menu using Javascript as that&#8217;s the only way to do it currently.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.1.3</h4>
<ul>
<li>Move the <code>error_reporting()</code> call in the AJAX handler to the beginning so that we&#8217;re more sure that no PHP errors are outputted. Some hosts disable usage of <code>set_time_limit()</code> and calling it was causing a PHP warning to be outputted.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.1.2</h4>
<ul>
<li>When regenerating all images, newest images are done first rather than the oldest.</li>
<li>Fixed a bug with regeneration error reporting in some browsers. Thanks to pete-sch for reporting the error.</li>
<li>Supress PHP errors in the AJAX handler to avoid sending an invalid JSON response. Thanks to pete-sch for reporting the error.</li>
<li>Better and more detailed error reporting for when <code>wp_generate_attachment_metadata()</code> fails.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.1.1</h4>
<ul>
<li>Clean up the wording a bit to better match the new features and just be easier to understand.</li>
<li>Updated screenshots.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.1.0</h4>
<p>Lots of new features!</p>
<ul>
<li>Thanks to a lot of jQuery help from <a href="http://borisschapira.com/" rel="nofollow ugc">Boris Schapira</a>, a failed image regeneration will no longer stop the whole process.</li>
<li>The results of each image regeneration is now outputted. You can easily see which images were successfully regenerated and which failed. Was inspired by a concept by Boris.</li>
<li>There is now a button on the regeneration page that will allow you to abort resizing images for any reason. Based on code by Boris.</li>
<li>You can now regenerate single images from the Media page. The link to do so will show up in the actions list when you hover over the row.</li>
<li>You can now bulk regenerate multiple from the Media page. Check the boxes and then select &#8220;Regenerate Thumbnails&#8221; form the &#8220;Bulk Actions&#8221; dropdown. WordPress 3.1+ only.</li>
<li>The total time that the regeneration process took is now displayed in the final status message.</li>
<li>jQuery UI Progressbar version upgraded.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.0.3</h4>
<ul>
<li>Switch out deprecated function call.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.0.2</h4>
<ul>
<li>Directly query the database to only fetch what the plugin needs (the attachment ID). This will reduce the memory required as it&#8217;s not storing the whole row for each attachment.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.0.1</h4>
<ul>
<li>I accidentally left a <code>check_admin_referer()</code> (nonce check) commented out.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 2.0.0</h4>
<ul>
<li>Recoded from scratch. Now uses an AJAX request per attachment to do the resizing. No more PHP maximum execution time errors or anything like that. Also features a pretty progress bar to let the user know how it&#8217;s going.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 1.1.0</h4>
<ul>
<li>WordPress 2.7 updates &#8212; code + UI. Thanks to jdub and Patrick F.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Version 1.0.0</h4>
<ul>
<li>Initial release.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Upgrade Notice</h4>
<p>Support for WordPress 5.3</p>

<p>This is useful for situations such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>A new thumbnail size has been added and you want past uploads to have a thumbnail in that size.</li>
<li>You&#8217;ve changed the dimensions of an existing thumbnail size, for example via Settings → Media.</li>
<li>You&#8217;ve switched to a new WordPress theme that uses featured images of a different size.</li>
</ul>
<p>It also offers the ability to delete old, unused thumbnails in order to free up server space.</p>
<h4>In Memory of Alex Mills</h4>
<p>In February 2019 Alex Mills, the author of this plugin, <a href="https://alex.blog/2019/02/27/from-alexs-family/" rel="nofollow ugc">passed away</a>. He leaves behind a number of plugins which will be maintained by Automattic and members of the WordPress community. If this plugin is useful to you please consider donating to the Oregon Health and Science University. You can find more information <a href="https://alex.blog/2019/03/13/in-memory-of-alex-donation-link-update/" rel="nofollow ugc">here</a>.</p>
<h4>Alternatives</h4>
<p><strong>WP-CLI</strong></p>
<p>If you have command line access to your server, I highly recommend using <a href="https://wp-cli.org/" rel="nofollow ugc">WP-CLI</a> instead of this plugin as it&#8217;s faster (no HTTP requests overhead) and can be run inside of a <code>screen</code> for those with many thumbnails. For details, see the documentation of its <a href="https://developer.wordpress.org/cli/commands/media/regenerate/" rel="nofollow ugc"><code>media regenerate</code> command</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Jetpack&#8217;s Photon Module</strong></p>
<p><a href="https://jetpack.com/" rel="nofollow ugc">Jetpack</a> is a plugin by Automattic, makers of WordPress.com. It gives your self-hosted WordPress site some of the functionality that is available to WordPress.com-hosted sites.</p>
<p><a href="https://jetpack.com/support/photon/" rel="nofollow ugc">The Photon module</a> makes the images on your site be served from WordPress.com&#8217;s global content delivery network (CDN) which should speed up the loading of images. Importantly though it can create thumbnails on the fly which means you&#8217;ll never need to use this plugin.</p>
<p>I personally use Photon on my own website.</p>
<p><em>Disclaimer: I work for Automattic but I would recommend Photon even if I didn&#8217;t.</em></p>
<h4>Need Help? Found A Bug? Want To Contribute Code?</h4>
<p>Support for this plugin is provided via the <a href="https://wordpress.org/support/plugin/regenerate-thumbnails">WordPress.org forums</a>.</p>
<p>The source code for this plugin is available on <a href="https://github.com/automattic/regenerate-thumbnails" rel="nofollow ugc">GitHub</a>.</p>
